text: hi everyone fresh out of the shower here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new alex
cameron album oxi music this is the
newest and fourth full-length lp from
singer and songwriter mr alex cameron
who quickly grew to be one of my
favorites of the 2010s off of a few
records i even named his track far from
born again my favorite song and single
of 2019 so i've really loved the guy's
work for a minute now and one of my
favorite consistent things about alex
cameron's music is not just his ability
to write a song but embody it act within
it bring a vivid character to a song or
an entire record whether that be jumping
the shark which was a concept record
about a tv host and personality whose
livelihood in the entertainment industry
was being torn away from him or forced
witness which is a project where alex
plays out in first person the
perspective of a series of toxic meat
heads and pervs and seedy individuals
the record miami memory had its share of
personalities too but it mostly felt
like a mask off moment for alex where he
was really able to put very clearly his
actual opinions on the prejudice and the
sexism and the narrow-mindedness that
often inspires the characters that he
puts into his songs but oxymusic i think
sees him going back into a persona a
little bit i think sometimes it is hard
to tell because he does put a lot of
himself and his actual points of view in
his songs and he's so good at blurring
the lines between fantasy and reality
but what's clear if the title doesn't
already make it obvious is this record
is very much about drugs especially
through the experience of addiction and
the emotional and mental lows that come
along with that there's a bit of a
stylistic shift musically to complement
this thematic angle too the
instrumentals on this one are a lot less
quirky new wave and heartland rock and
more smooth synth pop and soft rock
instead which i think is a smart
contrast given how vibey and blissful
these genres often are but much of the
time this record lacks the lush layering
and maybe even the budget to make this
sound really come to fruition like on
the track prescription refill for
example which i think checks some basic
soft rock boxes but still the faint
rhythm guitars and rickety drums lack a
certain kind of smoothness and color
then there's hold the line which i
cannot really make heads or tails of
what this song is attempting the
stuttering drum patterns on this one
have the worst groove on top of it the
rest of the rhythm section makes the
awful choice of just kind of locking in
with it for the verses alex's lyricism
here i don't think is up to snuff either
sure the addiction narrative does come
through pretty clearly but i'm wearing
my blossom robe but i can't even get it
up so how am i supposed to give a [ __ ]
cash stuffed in my underpants i'm
overflowing watch me dance mosquito mass
hysteria i'm serving up malaria i know
alex is fairly self-aware when it comes
to his lyrics and he's obviously trying
to be a little humorous here but he's
had way funnier asides on previous
tracks and way more telling ones too
when it comes to describing and letting
the listener understand his or his
character's motivations the vocal
performance on this one feels weirdly
understated for alex too as if he's kind
of given up on selling his songs which
he's typically pretty great at like as
he shifts into the chorus on the song
there's no noticeable change in emotion
intensity much of anything it's kind of
like he's just sauntering through
multiple passages of this lp with casual
shower singing even on moments where i
think he's bringing far superior
songwriting like on the song best life
which describes i think an addiction of
a different kind the need for validation
on social media or sarah joe whose very
funny lyrics are packed with all these
descriptions of toxic antisocial
behavior which as it's described here
seems to be pulling a family apart still
even though there are spots at this lp
where it seems like something is missing
alex's pop sensibilities and weirdo
charms ring through especially on k-hole
which i think is the perfect mix of
beauty and tragedy that makes alex
cameron's best moments so magic the
smooth and carefree grooves on this one
play really well against alex's lyrical
struggle to maintain composure and
stability in the midst of uh taking way
too much ketamine all the time this is
also the one track i have not been able
to stop playing since this record came
out there are some lyrics also on this
track that address mental health which i
also think is a recurring theme on this
project especially on some of the
sleepier cuts here such as breakdown or
dead eyes the latter of which might be a
little too lethargic for my tastes but
breakdown's cries for sympathy and
understanding after having lost it are
pretty strong and compelling and
certainly serve as a reminder that we
are not our mental illnesses but nothing
on this lp could have prepared me for
what i was going to be hit with in its
final moments there is cancel culture
which is uh honest to god a zany
lo-fi hip-hop kind of pop rock reggae
fusion the keys are nuts the guest
rapper lloyd vines i don't know where
alex got this guy but uh he brings some
character to the track then vocally alex
is going off on the song in a way that
he just has not been for oxy music up
until this point so this thing is
colorful it's messy it's out there but
what's even more interesting is what
he's saying about this continually
controversial topic because alex does a
pretty decent job of sidestepping any
obvious takes on uh cancel culture
making the song more about the social
tensions that may arise in the midst of
appropriating culture or vernacular that
is not yours especially as a white guy
which the track is obviously poking fun
at but simultaneously the takeaway seems
to be so if you're worried about the
vultures the only thing we can do is
cancel culture which is certainly a way
of looking at it either way the hook
sticks i think it's generally a fun and
thoughtful track but still the
instrumental the genre fusions here
really could have gone over a lot
smoother then the closing track features
jason williamson of sleaford modsfame
and has some of the most homegrown
production on the entire lp sounding
like
some weird lost
lo-fi 80s synthy pop rock demo
thematically it does tie up a lot of
this record's themes of drugs addiction
trying to kick that addiction it's a
lengthy cut to and undergoes a pretty
grand shift in the second half but
williamson and alex vocally mix like oil
and water on this one especially when
their vocals are
harmonizing i use that term loosely uh
on the back end which honestly i think
more has to do with placement than
performance jason williamson for the
most part on the track is fine he does
on the song what uh we know him to do on
many a sleeford's track and i'm sure
going into this song that's exactly what
alex wanted from him but i just don't
think uh how it marries here it comes
together as well as maybe alex uh thinks
it it may so sadly overall i think this
record is a bit of an off one for alex
even if it does have a few highlights on
it the production and performances
consistently i just think are not up to
snuff for him there are a lot of lyrical
potholes strewn about the lp2 and beyond
that we have a concept that feels only
slightly dug into not just on individual
tracks but the record as a whole
especially with the tracklist feeling a
little short kind of feeling a light six
on this one
tran position have you given this
project a listen did you love it did you
hate it what would you rate it you're
the best you're the best what should i
review next hit the like if you like
please subscribe and please don't cry
hit the bell as well over here next to
my head it's another video you can check
out hit that up or the link to subscribe
to the channel anthony fantano alex
cameron oxymusic
forever
